source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The Hanford Site N Reactor core includes approximately 1000 Zircaloy-2 pressure tubes

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: the overall tube length is 16.1 m

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: the central fueled length is 10.6 m

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: coolant temperature increases from 204 to 282°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: waterside oxide layer thickness increases uniformly from ~3 μm to a maximum of over 50 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The outer surface oxidation levels are approximately an order of magnitude less

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: oxide thicknesses have steadily increased with operating time

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: in-flux oxidation rates are clearly enhanced relative to ex-reactor Zircaloy oxidation rates

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: in-flux oxidation rate varies exponentially with absolute temperature

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: in-flux oxidation rate at a given temperature increases significantly as the oxide layer thickness passes from <15 μm to >20 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen content in the tube wall along the fueled region follows the axial distribution of the oxide thickness

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen accumulation rate generally follows the oxidation rate

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen accumulation rate increases as the waterside oxidation passes from the thin-film (<15 μm) regime to the thick-film (>20 μm) regime

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen content has a strong azimuthal distribution with the maximum occurring at the top of the tube

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrogen has a strong radial distribution with the maximum occurring at the tube inner surface

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: tubes are cold worked Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: inside diameter of 68.8 mm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: 6.8 mm nominal wall thickness

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: coolant enters the inlet end at 202°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: outlet value of 282°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: coolant is pressurized light water (10.7 MPa)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The waterside (inside diameter), oxide layer thickness increased uniformly from approximately 3 μm (the preinstallation value) at the inlet to a maximum of over 50 μm near the peak neutron flux location

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The gas side (outer diameter) oxidation levels were about an order of magnitude less than the waterside oxidation

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: beyond ~2500 operating days (at oxide thicknesses greater than 15 to 20 μm, the oxidation and hydriding rates increased sharply

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The azimuthal correction never exceeded 8°C (15°F), above or below average coolant temperature

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: total temperature rise for the tube, 78‰ EMPY (140°F)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: increase in the oxidation rate as the thicknesses passed from <15 μm to >20 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: the thin-film $( < 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ regime

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: the thick-film $( > 2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ regime

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: the in-flux oxidation rate is definitely less than that of Hillner's correlation

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: the in-flux rates are enhanced (by factors of 20 to 60) at any given temperature relative to Hillner's ex-reactor rates

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: very high (>500 ppm) hydrogen content in the innermost 20% of the wall

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: lower and relatively constant concentrations (50 to 100 ppm) throughout the remainder of the wall

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: an azimuthal hydrogen survey was performed at 9.17 m on Tube 5053 with an average value of 190 ppm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The inner surface oxide layer thicknesses determined at that same axial position at 12:00 and 6:00 were 42 and 41 μm, respectively, implying an azimuthal average of 41.5 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The inner surface oxide layer thicknesses determined at that same axial position at 12:00 and 6:00 were 42 and 41 μm, respectively, implying an azimuthal average of 41.5 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The inner surface oxide layer thicknesses determined at that same axial position at 12:00 and 6:00 were 42 and 41 μm, respectively, implying an azimuthal average of 41.5 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: estimated utilization factor of 1.1 (that is, apparent absorption of all corrosion produced hydrogen)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic calculations have shown that plausible fuel element eccentricity within the tube can cause flow redistribution and azimuthal (bottom-to-top) temperature gradients of $1 7 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ EPY $( 6 3 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { F } )$ at the 9.14 to $9 . 3 7 ~ \mathrm { \ m }$ location

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: The observed maximum-to-minimum difference for Tube 1054 at $1 0 . 1 6 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ is $1 5 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ (Fig. 8)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Sawatzky's equations predicted a difference of $1 8 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$

evidence_span: the oxidation rate and hydrogen accumulation rate both increase by a factor of 2 to 3 as oxide thicknesses exceed 15 to $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

evidence_span: the oxidation rate and hydrogen accumulation rate both increase by a factor of 2 to 3 as oxide thicknesses exceed 15 to $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Oxidation and deuterium uptake in Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes are being monitored

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: no evidence for any acceleration in the oxidation rate for exposures up to about 4500 effective full power days

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: deuterium uptake in Zr-2.5Nb tubes has been remarkably low and no greater than 3 mg/kg deuterium per year (0.39 mg/dm² hydrogen per year)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: deuterium uptake in Zr-2.5Nb tubes has been remarkably low and no greater than 3 mg/kg deuterium per year (0.39 mg/dm² hydrogen per year)
